title: 106_hr1399
content: The "Fairness for Legal Immigrants Act of 1999" allows certain alien pregnant women and children to be eligible for Medicaid. The "Fairness for Legal Immigrants Act of 1999" permits states to waive certain Medicaid eligibility requirements for pregnant women and children who are lawfully residing in the United States. This includes battered aliens and optional targeted low-income children. The "Fairness for Legal Immigrants Act of 1999" allows states to waive Medicaid eligibility requirements for pregnant women and children who are lawfully residing in the US. Section 213A(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to exclude state waiver benefits from means-tested public benefits. Conforming amendments are made to the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996. The Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 is amended to include references to section 405 in various sections. The amendments made by this section will be retroactive in effect. The amendment made by this section shall be retroactive and take effect as if included in the enactment of the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996, except for a specific amendment related to the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996. Optional eligibility of immigrant children for SCHIP. Optional SCHIP eligibility for certain aliens is granted by an amendment to the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996. States have the option to waive certain eligibility requirements for child health assistance under the State child health plan for children lawfully residing in the United States. The waiver for child health assistance eligibility is only valid when the State has an election in place for children. The amendment applies to coverage starting on or after October 1, 1997. SEC. 4. OPTIONAL ELIGIBILITY OF CERTAIN MEDICALLY NEEDY ALIENS FOR MEDICAID. Optional eligibility for certain blind or disabled medically needy aliens admitted after August 22, 1996, under the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996. Individuals who are considered blind or disabled under the Social Security Act may be eligible for medical assistance under specific clauses. The amendment made by paragraph (1) in the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 allows for optional eligibility of medically needy aliens requiring a certain level of care. Optional eligibility for medically needy aliens requiring a certain level of care can be waived by states under the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996. This applies to aliens lawfully residing in the US since August 22, 1996, who are residents of nursing facilities or require similar care. The amendment made by paragraph (1) of the Act shall take effect as if included in the enactment of title IV of the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996. Eligibility of certain aliens for SSI. Eligibility for SSI is addressed for aged aliens lawfully residing in the United States on August 22, 1996, and blind or disabled qualified aliens who entered the US after that date. Amendments are made to the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996. Amendments to the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 include an exception for blind or disabled qualified aliens who entered the United States after August 22, 1996, regarding eligibility for the SSI program. The Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 is amended to include an exception for blind or disabled aliens regarding certain programs. Enforcement of affidavits of support is also addressed in the amendments. The amendments address enforcement of affidavits of support for individuals eligible for benefits under the Immigration and Nationality Act. Effective date for benefits is based on applications filed after the enactment of the Act. The amendment allows legal immigrants residing in the US before August 22, 1996, to be exempt from food stamp eligibility restrictions. The effective date for this amendment applies to benefits under the food stamp program 30 days after the Act's enactment. Legal immigrants suffering from domestic abuse are eligible for benefits under the food stamp program. Legal immigrants suffering from domestic abuse are eligible for benefits under the food stamp program. Amendments have been made to exempt battered immigrants from certain bans under the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996. Amendments to the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 allow benefits to be provided to battered immigrants to alleviate harm or avoid cruelty in the future. Amendments to the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 include changes to sponsor deeming and the definition of "family" for battered immigrants accessing federal public benefits. Amendments to the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 now allow individuals covered by domestic violence statutes to sponsor battered immigrants for federal public benefits. Amendments to the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 now allow individuals covered by domestic violence statutes to sponsor battered immigrants for federal public benefits, expanding the eligibility to include a broader range of relationships and circumstances. The amendments allow individuals covered by domestic violence statutes to sponsor battered immigrants for federal public benefits, effective on the date of enactment of this Act.
